field_edited_text.value:
*Environmental Issues: Several environ-
mental issues figure in the future of
Hawkins Point. While connected to the
City’s water supply and storm water
systems, the area is without public sanitary
sewers. This means that businesses in the
area must maintain their own package (i.e.
self-contained) treatment systems and resi-
dences must use septic tanks. For busi-
nesses that are considering locating in
Hawkins Point, the prospect of having to
install a package treatment system repre-
sents an added development cost.

A federally-sponsored Areawide Waste-
water Management Study has been com-
pleted to assess the need for public sewer
service in Hawkins Point. The study has
concluded that public sewers are needed,
there are a number of ways this need could
be met, including connecting the area to
the City’s Patapsco Wastewater Treatment
+Plant in Fairfield, connecting it to the Cox
Creek Plant in Anne Arundel County, and
connecting the residential community to a
sewer system at the U.S. Coast Guard
Station. However, the unavailability of
federal funds for extending sewer service
to industrial areas leaves the burden of
financing comprehensive sewer service to
Hawkins Point to local jurisdictions.

As in other harbor areas, the develop-
ment of a major coal terminal near

Dust clouds from unloading ore

]ay Steinhour

Hawkins Point requires that dust emissions
from coal cars, coal piles, and loading and
unloading operations be controlled. The
State air quality agency believes that
planned controls on the coal loading
operations would sufficiently limit any
emissions.

There is also concern over the leaking
of pollutants into the bay from the Glidden
Co.’s holding ponds. Acid, leaking through
the dikes of:these ponds has reached the
shallow water area along the shoreline of
the plant. There has already been damage
to wetlands vegetation and the water qual-
ity in the area. The state and Glidden are
currently negotiating solutions to this
problem.

*Port-Related Issue: There are signifi-
cant opportunities for port-related devel-
opment along the northern shoreline of
Hawkins Poing because the land here has
deep water access. However, the waters off
the north shore have served for years as a
disposal site for unwanted “dead” ships.
Thus, before the northern shore can be
developed for activities requiring deep-
water access, the sunken ships in these
waters will have to be cleared.



51
